question: Ahhhh... The sweet, uncomplicated satisfaction of The Younger Woman. That fleeting age when everything just falls right into place. It's magic time and it can render any man, anywhere -- absolutely helpless. Some say I'm an expert on The Younger Woman. Guess that's 'cause I've been dating them for over forty years... Langer. .. The Maitre'd snaps to attention at the sight of him. So what does a life of bucking the system all add up to? To never settle down with the right woman for a life of leftovers and Christmas mornings. No his and her IRA accounts, no mini van parked in the garage. I think it's made me what I am today. The luckiest son of a bitch on earth. Look at me. I'm positively debonair. I should be illegal I'm lookin' so good. Harry passes a table where a BEATEN SIXTY YEAR OLD dines with his AGE APPROPRIATE, WELL-FED WIFE. IN SLOW MOTION, Harry and The Beaten Man catch each other's glance. It isn't as if I haven't wondered what my life would be like if I was a Regular Joe and came in here once a month with a dame my age' for a porterhouse and a side of I spinach. I've wondered... No, come on, let's be honest. ..a dame really my age. . . There you have it. The story in a nutshell. Not exactly debonair, am I? Awww, man, it's down right sad. Look at me. I look like I'm about to die. God help me. I do not want to die.
answer: To all my thugs that be livin' it up, we say, what I do. To all my... Oh! This is it. Make a right.

question: So baby, you're rich... .

question: So put on your bathing suit. I brought some champagne, I'll put it on ice.

question: No, it's what makes you strong. You've never really understood this,but we're not all like you. question: I know. But why would I do that? They're so elegant. Nice piping...
answer: Mr. Langer, you're always giving away beautiful things.

question: Mom, we're going into town... Erica turns, wiping tears. Are you crying? I didn't know you did that.
answer: Yeah, it's my new thing. I've gotten abnormally great at it.

question: Is it Harry?
answer: Seems I gotta learn how to do that love 'em and leave 'em stuff.

question: Fucking men. You don't care when I say fuck, do you?
answer: Not really. Sometimes. Not right now.

question: So now you get my theory about love? You gotta self protect. It's too dangerous.
answer: Marin, that theory... how can I put this so your feelings won't get hurt. It's just so crazy, it makes me want to SCREAMMMMMMMMMMM!!!!

question: And how would you put it if you wanted to hurt my feelings?
answer: Listen to me... you cannot hide from love for the rest of your life because maybe it won't work out and maybe you'll become unglued. That's not a way to live.

question: So you're telling me you're happy right now? This is good what happened to you?
answer: No. This was bad. But for the three days it was good, it was electrifying. Marin's eyes fill up. I think you must consider the possibility that we are more alike than you realize. I let someone in and I had the time of my life.

question: I've never had the time of my life.
answer: I know. And bubbee, I say this from the deepest part of my heart. . ... what the fuck are you waiting "for?

question: These are for you to give me when you apologize.
answer: Julian, I hope you know I'm mortified by my behavior. I was going to get in touch with you, send you a note or something...

question: A note? That's a little chilly.
answer: I'm embarrassed. I just haven't been myself lately. What can I say?

question: Just tell me you're sorry.
answer: I am sorry.

question: Then you could kiss me.
answer: Kiss you? ulian nods. You'll forgive me if I kiss' you?

question: Think so. Erica hesitates then gives him a peck of a kiss. No one on earth would forgive you for that kiss May I? Erica nods as Julian takes her in his arms and gives her a kiss that doesn't quit. I forgive you. Erica very distinctly begins to hear the BEATING of her own heart. It's the best thing you've ever written.
answer: It is?

question: I need to talk to you. Erica freezes, horrified. Turns, sees him. Got a minute? So your play's about us?
answer: No, it's about me.

question: Am I in it?
answer: A guy like you is in it but he's not you.

question: What happens to this guy who's ..not me?
answer: Haven't totally decided. He can live or he can die.

question: What are you leaning towards?
answer: Death. It's funnier.

question: He dies of a funny heart attack?
answer: He's sort of a schmuck who screwed around with our heroine, so it won't be too sad.

question: Schmucks are people too you know. Death doesn't seem a little harsh?
answer: I just went where the story took me. It's a work of fiction, Harry. Really...just stuff I made up.

question: So I'm going to be the laughing stock of Broadway.
answer: Harry, he's not you. He's a version of the truth of you. So to speak. Right. We now HEAR Louis Armstrong's La Vie En Rose play throughout the theater. The BEACH backing is 'raised and an EIFFEL TOWER BACKING is lowered behind them. They both try to ignore the music, but it's impossible.

question: You know it isn't like I wanted to stop seeing you. We could've carried on a fun thing for awhile. Why is it you dames want all or nothing?
answer: I don't know, we're just goofy when it comes to love... Look, Harry, if it's all right with you, I'd like to be friends

question: I'm not ready to be your friend. How's that?
answer: Fine. I understand.

question: Anyway, do you actually buy that horse shit.. .that men and women can be friends once they've had sex?
answer: I'm friends with my ex-husband, but then again, we didn't just have sex.

question: We didn't just have sex either.
answer: Then what was it? Love to know.

question: Can I e-mail it to you when I figure it out? This is perfect. I have given the `Can't We Be friends' speech for 40 years. I think I invented the 'Can't We Be Friends' speech. But you know what,now I get why they never went for it. You dames got one thing right. Sometimes sex does change everything. Call me crazy, but I just don't see us out on the town, being pals, having dinner, 'cause I'd bet you anything, at some point, one of us will have very unfriend like thoughts about the other then pass the bread becomes anything but pass the bread. You get what I'm saying?
answer: You don't want to be friends.

question: Not "don't". Can't. Can't be friends. Doesn't work that way. Okay, I'm moving into another phase of this thing. I'm mad at you. It almost feels good.
answer: I think I'm mad at you too.

question: Excellent. 'Cause I don't like thinking about you so much and worrying about how you are and if I ruined your life or...
answer: -- You've worried about me?

question: Yes honey, the schmuck who deserves to die, worries about you.
answer: Well, doll, I'm doing fine. So you don't have to work that shift anymore. Again, The Stage Manager...

question: You never change, do you? Surprised, Harry turns, glances over at the Woman. She drinks from a water bottle then offers him an easy warm smile. She's adorable, mid-sixties, short grey hair.
answer: Do you know me or are you just talking to me as "man" in general, the beast women love to hate.

question: No, no, I know you Harry.
answer: Oh. Don't tell me. I dated your daughter. Right? I broke her heart then she married some hard working Joe on the rebound, has three great kids. What is so funny?

question: You dated me and you broke my heart but after you I met the right guy. I've been married thirty-seven years, have four kids, eight grandkids and a ninth on the way. Harry now fully turns in her direction, totally clueless.
answer: I dated you. .? Did we. ever...?

question: No...we did not. He looks at her hard but still doesn't remember her.
answer: Can you give me hint? A year? A decade?

question: The sixties. You took me to Shea Stadium.
answer: To a Mets game? I must've really liked you.

question: You took me to see The Beatles.
answer: Oh, God, I really liked you. You're Sandra. ..Cook. We did. We saw The Beatles together. How the hell have you been? What happened to you?

question: Oh, God, I really liked you. You're Sandra. ..Cook. We did. We saw The Beatles together. How the hell have you been? What happened to you?
answer: Mr. Langer... Back so soon.

question: This is it, I'm dyin', I've had 20 minutes of severe chest pain, nausea, shortness of breath, blood pressure's gotta be 170 over 100. Give me the nitrate, I didn't take viagra. Plug me in to the EKG, I need an aspirin, I'm taking 2 beta blockers, blood thinner, Lipitor, Procardia and if I were you, I'd be pounding my chest. Ow! Just a very sick man.
answer: Mr. Langer, your diagnosis although fascinating, was entirely incorrect.

question: That's impossible.
answer: Your realize a severe anxiety attack can masquerade as a heart attack.

question: So I'm nuts? Perfect! The one thing I'm not taking pills for.
answer: If you don't want ,to end up in here every week, I suggest you do whatever it takes to decompress. Try something with me, okay? Close your eyes...now give yourself a visual image of something that gives you a feeling of peace and serenity.

question: I don't know. A hammock... Palm trees...clear blue water... We hear the SOUND OF LAPPING WATER, SEA GULLS. . . .
answer: Anybody there with you?

question: Yes. Beautiful women...in thongs...
answer: Okay. What else do you see, feel, taste...

question: A margarita...a Cuban cigar. ..miles of soft beach.. .
answer: Keep going...you're doing great... And as Harry keeps listing things, Camera MOVES IN ON HIM as the STEEL BAND gets LOUDER AND LOUDER.

question: I couldn't believe you were calling from downstairs. So great to see you.
answer: You couldn't look better.

question: Thank you. Come on in.
answer: No, no, I just wanted to stop by and say hi and tell you I'm sorry if I ever did anything to you that wasn't on the up and up or...

question: What do you mean? You were great to me.
answer: I was?

question: Always.
answer: That's refreshing. Good. Well, I don't know what you've done to yourself but you look absolutely radiant.

question: I'm three months pregnant, that might have something to do with it. My husband, hold on, he really wants to meet you. Danny... A Solid Citizen of a Guy joins Marin, loosened tie, glasses... Harry Langer, my husband, Danny Yellin.
answer: I bet.. .

question: Just to us. In every interview my Mom does, she always says she made you up.
answer: So the guy in the play, he doesn't make it, does he? Was hopin' she'd give me a reprieve, but...

question: Yeah, well...
answer: Yeah. Okay...Best of luck, kids... Marin is stumped by this little visit. Harry heads toward the elevator, pushes the button, then turns back. How is she?

question: She's. . . Really good. Up to her old tricks. Learning Italian, remodeling her apartment in the city.
answer: Now if I wanted to see her...how would that go over?

question: Only one way to find out, except she's out of town right now.
answer: Oh yeah? Where is she?

question: Paris. She left two days ago, for her birthday. But she'll be back next week... The Elevator arrives. Harry salutes his goodbye and steps INSIDE THE ELEVATOR. He turns, FACES CAMERA.
answer: Paris... Showtirne. I knew you'd be here.

question: Paris... Showtirne. I knew you'd be here.
answer: You did?

question: I've come a long way to see you, Erica.
answer: You mean we're not bumping into each other..? You came here to see me?

question: Yes, I did. I'm aware it was a bold move, one of those impulses that grabs you,' but...so far, we're okay; right?
answer: Well, uh, I mean, I'm just...

question: I'll take that as a 'Yes'. Harry takes off his coat and scarf, hangs them on a hook.
answer: You want a glass of wine or something?

question: I was just gonna give you a kiss hello.
answer: Oh, Okay. Neither is sure where to go. Cheek? Lips? He lands on her chin. .Not what he wanted, but he takes a seat across from her. She looks at him - utterly speechless.

question: I remember you said if we still know each other we should go to Paris for our birthdays, well, we still know each other..".
answer: That's true, but, Harry, I haven't heard from you in six months.

question: I know but I've certainly been thinking about you. There's a lot I have to say. First thing is... I'm not mad at you anymore.
answer: Good, 'cause I'm not mad at you anymore either.

question: That's a relief...since I did come all the way to France and everything. And... Happy Birthday.
answer: Thank you.

question: And congratulations on your amazing success...
answer: It's been quite a ride. Funny, I thought maybe I'd hear from you when it opened. Where've you been?

question: After I saw you in the theater that afternoon, I had another "episode...
answer: Oh, I'm sorry.

question: No, no, I insist. I crashed your party. At least let me buy you dinner on your birthday... What time does that say?
answer: I have no idea...

question: Wait,' I have my. . .
answer: Me too... They each take out EACH OTHER'S GLASSES and put them on. Erica points to Harry wearing her glasses and laughs.

question: You think you look so handsome in mine?
answer: You know how long I've been looking for those?
